title: How does Boise State’s rushing offense this season compare to their last three seasons and the rest of the College Football?
text:
Boise State is still performing well in total rushing yards, as they are currently third in the Mountain West Conference with 1664 rushing yards. These stats are 9 games in, so they don’t include this past weekend’s Boise State game. All of my stats came from CFB Stats.
What makes this bar chart interesting? Boise State is 36th in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) in total rushing yards so far this year. So they are doing just fine. Not to mention that it’s better than Nebraska. Do they have a better running back than Nebraska? No. Individual stats will tell you that. Are they a better team than Nebraska? No. Nebraska would win that match-up by at least two scores. Just watching college football will tell you that. Still, Boise State’s rushing offense is interesting and has been for years.


Code
library(tidyverse)

rushing25 <- read_csv("rushing25.csv")

mountainwestconference <- rushing25 |>
  filter(
    Name == "Air Force" |
    Name == "Boise State" |
    Name == "Colorado State" |
    Name == "Fresno State" |
    Name == "Hawaii" |
    Name == "Nevada" |
    Name == "New Mexico" |
    Name == "San Diego State" |
    Name == "San Jose State" |
    Name == "Utah State" |
    Name == "Wyoming" |
    Name == "UNLV"
  )

boisest <- mountainwestconference |>
  filter(
    Name == "Boise State"
  )

ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data = mountainwestconference,
           aes(x = reorder(Name, Yards), weight = Yards), fill = "lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data = boisest,
           aes(x = reorder(Name, Yards), weight = Yards), fill = "blue") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    title = "So far this year Boise State is third in the\nMountain West Conference in total rushing\nyards",
    subtitle = "Boise State's Total Rushing Yards in 2025",
    x = "",
    y = "Total Rushing Yards",
    caption = "Source: CFB Stats\nBy: Isaac Thomas" 
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.margin = unit(c(20, 5.5, 5.5, 5.5), "pt")
  )









In 2024, Boise State finished ranked 8th in FBS in total rushing yards. This means they performed better than about 94% of teams when it comes to total rushing yards. These are team total rushing yards stats, but Ashton Jeanty, 2024 Heisman finalist runner-up, has a lot to do with these stats. He definitely had a major impact. I mean, he was first in FBS in total rushing yards with 2601. Others added to this, but he is the bulk of it.
Back to the point of this graph. In 2024, Boise State finished ranked 2nd in the Mountain West Conference in total rushing yards. Only a step better than this year so far, but that does not tell the whole story. Overall, in college football, rushing was better in 2024 than it is this year. This year’s Boise State probably won’t come close to their total rushing yards in 2024, which was 3365 total rushing yards.

Boise State established a dominant ground game throughout the 2023 season, accumulating 3,008 total rushing yards. This strong performance placed them among the nation’s elite, ranking 8th overall in the FBS for total rushing yards. Within their own league, the Mountain West Conference, the team’s production was second only to Air Force’s triple-option attack, cementing Boise State’s standing as the second-ranked rushing offense in the conference. This success on the ground was a fundamental driver of their offensive identity.

During the 2022 season, Boise State’s ground attack was highly effective, registering 2,749 total rushing yards. This performance was strong enough to secure the second spot in the Mountain West Conference rushing rankings, continuing the program’s tradition of dominance on the ground. Nationally, this total placed them reliably within the top third of the country, finishing the season 30th overall in the FBS for total team rushing yards.

This line chart tracks Boise State’s Rushing Yards Per Game (Yard/G) over the four seasons (2022–2025), isolating their performance (highlighted in blue) against the backdrop of all other NCAA teams (shown in gray). The data clearly indicates that Boise State’s rushing efficiency peaked in 2024, which marked the highest average with 240.36 yards per game. This represented a significant increase from the 2023 average of 214.86 yards per game and the 2022 average of 196.36 yards per game. The trend line shows a notable drop-off in the 2025 season, where the team averaged 184.89 yards per game. This comparison illustrates the dramatic rise and subsequent fall in the team’s season-by-season rushing output relative to the rest of college football.


Code
rushing22 <- read_csv("rushing22.csv") |>
  mutate(Season = 2022)

rushing23 <- read_csv("rushing23.csv") |>
  mutate(Season = 2023)

rushing24 <- read_csv("rushing24.csv") |>
  mutate(Season = 2024)

rushing25 <- read_csv("rushing25.csv") |>
  mutate(Season = 2025)

rushing_combined <- bind_rows(rushing22, rushing23, rushing24, rushing25)

boisest <- rushing_combined |>
  filter(Name == "Boise State")


ggplot(data = rushing_combined, aes(x = Season, y = `Yards/G`, group = Name)) + 
  
  geom_line(color = "lightgrey", alpha = 0.5, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_point(color = "lightgrey", alpha = 0.5, size = 1.5) + 
  
  geom_line(data = boisest, 
            color = "blue", 
            linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(data = boisest, 
             color = "blue", 
             size = 2.5) +
  
  
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(2022, 2023, 2024, 2025)) +
  
 
  labs(
    title = "Boise State Rushing Yards Per Game trended\nupwards until this year vs. All NCAA Teams (2022-2025)", 
    subtitle = "Rushing Yards Per Game (Yards/G) over four seasons.",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Rushing Yards Per Game (Yards/G)", 
    caption = "Source: CFB Stats\nBy: Isaac Thomas"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0, size = 8, face = "italic"),
    plot.margin = unit(c(15, 5.5, 5.5, 5.5), "pt")
  )









Boise State’s 2024 season stood out as the most dominant period in this four-year analysis, driven by elite rushing efficiency. The team achieved an impressive record of 12 wins and 2 losses, one of those losses being at the beginning of the season to Oregon by 3 points and their second loss being to Penn Sate in the college football playoff. This translated to an 85.7% win rate. This success coincided with a peak performance in the ground game, where the team averaged 6.06 yards per rush during the 2024 season. The scatterplot below visualizes this relationship, comparing the team’s average yards per rush to their seasonal win rate from 2022 to 2025, with the standout 2024 data point highlighted in blue in this scatter plot.
So far this season Boise State is 6-3 with an average of 4.75 yard per rush. In 2023 they were 8-6 with an average of 5.37 yards per rush and in 2022 they were 10-4 with an average of 4.99 yards per carry.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(scales) 

prepare_season_data <- function(year) {
  
  year_suffix <- substr(year, 3, 4) 
  rushing_file <- paste0("rushing", year_suffix, ".csv")
  record_file <- paste0("record", year_suffix, ".csv")
  
  rushing_data <- read_csv(rushing_file)
  record_data <- read_csv(record_file)
  
  rushing_data <- rushing_data |> 
    filter(Name == "Boise State") |>
    select(Name, Avg) 
  
  record_data <- record_data |> 
    filter(Split == "All Games") |> 
    mutate(
      Name = "Boise State",
      WinPct = Wins / (Wins + Losses)
    ) |>
    select(Name, WinPct) 
  
  merged_data <- inner_join(rushing_data, record_data, by = "Name") |>
    mutate(Season = as.factor(year))
  
  return(merged_data)
}

data_2022 <- prepare_season_data(2022)
data_2023 <- prepare_season_data(2023)
data_2024 <- prepare_season_data(2024)
data_2025 <- prepare_season_data(2025)

rushing_record_combined <- bind_rows(data_2022, data_2023, data_2024, data_2025)

season_colors <- c("2022" = "lightgrey", 
                   "2023" = "lightgrey", 
                   "2024" = "blue", 
                   "2025" = "lightgrey")

data_2024_highlight <- filter(rushing_record_combined, Season == "2024")

ggplot(data = rushing_record_combined, aes(x = WinPct, y = Avg)) +
  
  geom_point(aes(color = Season), 
             size = 6, 
             shape = 19) + 
  
  geom_point(data = data_2024_highlight,
             size = 8, 
             shape = 21,
             fill = "blue", 
             stroke = 1.5) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label = Season, 
                color = Season), 
            nudge_y = 0.08,
            vjust = -1.5,
            fontface = "bold",
            show.legend = FALSE) + 
  
  scale_color_manual(values = season_colors, 
                     name = "Season") + 
  
  scale_x_continuous() + 
  
  labs(
    title = "Boise State had their highest Average Yards\nper rush in the year 2024 which correlatted to\nthem having their highest win rate\nin last four years in same year",
    subtitle = "2024 (Highest Avg yards per rush & Win Rate) is highlighted in blue.",
    x = "Win Rate (Decimal)",
    y = "Average Yards Per Rush Attempt (Avg)",
    caption = "Source: CFB Stats\nBy: Isaac Thomas"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    legend.position = "right", 
    legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )









Boise State was elite in their rushing offense in 2024. They were decent the 2 seasons before and this season they are performing under their usual rushing status. They are still having a decent season but I believe they are only going to have another season like 2024 if their rushing attack gets back to being great.

title: Is 2012 Kentucky the best national champions in college basketball since 2010?
text:
The 2012 Kentucky Wildcats had a remarkable offensive season, finishing 7th in total points scored with 3,095 among all NCAA champions since 2010. What really set them apart, however, was their ability to get to the line. They led the group in free throw attempts with 938, showcasing their aggressive style of play and efficiency in drawing fouls. This combination of high scoring and prolific free throw attempts highlights Kentucky’s dominance on the court that year and underscores why they secured the championship.

This highlights the offensive and defensive performance of NCAA champions from 2010 to 2013. Each chart visualizes the proportion of points a team scored compared to the points they allowed, giving a quick sense of their dominance on the court. The 2012 Kentucky Wildcats stand out for their balanced yet high-powered offense, while 2010 Duke and 2013 Louisville show strong scoring capabilities as well. 2011 UConn demonstrates a more even distribution between points scored and allowed.

library(tidyverse)
library(waffle)
library(patchwork)

get_off_def <- function(df) {
  pts_col <- names(df)[grepl("^PTS", names(df))]
  
  team_val <- df |>
    filter(...1 == "Team") |>
    pull(all_of(pts_col)) |>
    as.numeric()
  
  opp_val <- df |>
    filter(...1 == "Opponent") |>
    pull(all_of(pts_col)) |>
    as.numeric()
  
  tibble(Offense = team_val, Defense = opp_val)
}

make_waffle_vec <- function(df_row, squares = 100) {
  df_row |>
    mutate(
      total = Offense + Defense,
      Offense = round(Offense / total * squares),
      Defense = round(Defense / total * squares)
    ) |>
    select(Offense, Defense) |>
    as.numeric() |>
    set_names(c("Offense", "Defense"))
}

kentucky_vec <- get_off_def(twentytwelveKentuckyone) |> make_waffle_vec()
duke_vec <- get_off_def(twentytenDuke) |> make_waffle_vec()
uconn_vec <- get_off_def(twentyelevenUconnone) |> make_waffle_vec()
louisville_vec <- get_off_def(twentythirteenLouisvilleone) |> make_waffle_vec()

kentucky_chart <- waffle(kentucky_vec, rows = 10, colors = c("blue", "gold"), title = "2012 Kentucky")
duke_chart <- waffle(duke_vec, rows = 10, colors = c("navy", "orange"), title = "2010 Duke")
uconn_chart <- waffle(uconn_vec, rows = 10, colors = c("darkblue", "gray"), title = "2011 UConn")
louisville_chart <- waffle(louisville_vec, rows = 10, colors = c("red", "black"), title = "2013 Louisville")

final_plot <- (kentucky_chart | duke_chart) /
              (uconn_chart | louisville_chart) +
              plot_annotation(
                title = "Showcasing NCAA Champions’ Offense and Defense Since 2010",
                subtitle = "The share of points scored versus points allowed.\n2013 Louisville, 2012 Kentucky, and 2010 Duke stand out.",
                caption = "Source: College Basketball Sports Reference | By Isaac Thomas"
              )

print(final_plot)








The 2012 Kentucky Wildcats stand out as the top scoring team among recent NCAA champions, posting a z-score of about 1.08 for points scored, meaning they scored more than one standard deviation above the average of champions from 2010 to 2014. This z-score highlights Kentucky’s offensive dominance in context, showing that their scoring was not just high in raw numbers but exceptional relative to other title-winning teams in this era. By standardizing points through z-scores, we can clearly see how Kentucky’s 2012 performance compares to other champions like 2010 Duke, 2011 UConn, 2013 Louisville, and 2014 UConn offering a more precise perspective on their offensive impact.

library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

pull_team_row <- function(df) {
  df |>
    filter(...1 == "Team") |>
    select(-...1) |>
    mutate(across(everything(), as.numeric))
}

champion_files <- list(
  `2010 Duke` = read_csv("2010Duke2.csv"),
  `2011 UConn` = read_csv("2011Uconn2.csv"),
  `2012 Kentucky` = read_csv("2012Kentucky2.csv"),
  `2013 Louisville` = read_csv("2013Louisville2.csv"),
  `2014 UConn` = read_csv("2014Uconn2.csv")
)

champions <- tibble(
  Team = names(champion_files),
  Data = map(champion_files, pull_team_row)
) |>
  unnest(Data)

champion_z <- champions |>
  mutate(
    across(
      .cols = where(is.numeric),
      .fns = ~ as.numeric(scale(.x)),
      .names = "z_{.col}"
    )
  )

champion_ranked <- champion_z |>
  select(Team, PTS, z_PTS) |>
  arrange(desc(z_PTS))

champion_ranked |>
  gt() |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Scoring Standouts Among NCAA Champions Since 2010",
    subtitle = "This table shows z-scores for points scored. Higher z-scores indicate teams that scored far above the era average, contextualizing Kentucky 2012 among other champions."
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = "Source: College Basketball Sports Reference | By: Isaac Thomas"
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white", weight = "bold")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "2012 Kentucky"
    )
  )

While no single metric tells the full story, the 2012 Kentucky Wildcats clearly leave a strong impression. Across the visualizations of offense versus defense, total points, and z-scored performance, Kentucky consistently ranks near the top, especially in scoring and free throw attempts. Yet, they do not lead every statistical category, showing that even a standout team has areas where others excel. Taken together with the eye test—watching their pace, depth (many future nba players on team including Anthony Davis and Michael Kidd-Gilchrist), and scoring efficiency—the 2012 Wildcats could be considered one of the best national championship teams of the last decade, even if they only dominate in select stats.
